content: The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2005" is cited as the short title. It excludes space-related income from gross income according to a new section added to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2005" adds a new section to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, stating that gross income shall not include space-related income. Space-related income includes income from products or services produced in outer space, services performed in outer space, and certain interest, rent, or royalties related to space activities. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2005" excludes space-related income from gross income. This includes income from services provided in outer space, transporting property to or from outer space, and proportional allocation for products produced partly in space. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2005" exempts products manufactured in outer space from federal tariffs and duties. Benefits will phase out gradually starting after December 31, 2014. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2005" exempts products made in outer space from federal tariffs and duties. Subchapter B of chapter 1 is amended to include a new item after section 139A. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2005" exempts space-related income from federal taxes starting in 2006. Additionally, a new section provides a credit for purchasing qualified space company stock. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2005" exempts space-related income from federal taxes starting in 2006. A new section offers a credit for buying qualified stock in a domestic C corporation that meets specific criteria related to gross receipts and space-based business activities. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2005" provides a tax credit for purchasing qualified stock in a domestic C corporation that is a qualified space company at the time of issuance. The stock must be acquired at its original issue in exchange for money or services, and the corporation must meet specific criteria to qualify as a qualified space company. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2005" offers a tax credit for buying qualified stock in a domestic C corporation that is a qualified space company. The corporation must meet active business requirements similar to section 1202(e) and be a C corporation. Rules similar to section 1202(c)(3) apply to the purchase of its own stock. If the issuer ceases to be a qualified space company within 10 years, the tax for that year increases by the decrease in credits allowed under section 38. This provision does not apply to stock acquired after December 31, 2013. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2005" provides a tax credit for purchasing qualified stock in a domestic C corporation that is a qualified space company. The credit is part of the general business credit under section 38(b) of the tax code. Amendments are made to sections 38(b) and 196(c) to include the space company investment credit. This provision does not apply to stock acquired after December 31, 2013. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2005" introduces a Space Company Investment Credit under section 45J. The amendments apply to costs incurred after December 31, 2005. Additionally, a Capital Gains Exclusion for gains from the sale of stock of qualified space corporations is added under section 1203 of the Internal Revenue Code. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2005" introduces a Capital Gains Exclusion for qualified space corporations. This provision excludes gain on the sale or exchange of stock of a qualified space corporation from gross income. A qualified space corporation is defined as a domestic C corporation organized for providing products or services in outer space, with at least 90% of expenses related to this activity. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2005" introduces a Capital Gains Exclusion for qualified space corporations, excluding gains from the sale or exchange of stock. The amendment applies to taxable years starting after December 31, 2005.
